repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.langmaterial: English. There are some materials in Spanish as well.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Collection is partially restricted. Selected materials are closed to use until 2050.
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Victoria Ortiz Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Victoria Ortiz Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2003 and 2005.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Virginia L. Daley, Paula Jeannet, Ann Langford, Lois Schultz, Pavla Vesela, Fuad Naeem, and Elizabeth Arnold
Accession(s) described in this collection guide: 2003-0066, 2003-0204, and 2005-0024.
Completed September 29, 2003 and materials added in 2005.
Encoded by Paula Jeannet, Lisa Stark, Elizabeth Arnold

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Activist and author, currently on the faculty of the UC-Berkeley School of Law; daughter of Bobbye S. Ortiz.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The Victoria Ortiz Papers span the years 1923 to 1999, with the majority of the papers dating from 1960 to 1990. The main collection (2003-0204) comprises materials separated from the Bobbye S. Ortiz Papers and consists of one series; the accession number 2003-0204 was assigned to this grouping. Viki Ortiz's political and intellectual interests can be gleaned from the topics in the Victoria Ortiz Subject Files Series, which has been divided into seven subseries to facilitate its use. The first three subseries contain newspaper and magazine articles, organizational materials, photographs, pamphlets, speeches, and reports related to Cuba, Mexico, and Latin America. Scholars of U.S. anticommunism and student movements in the 1960s may find of interest materials related to Ortiz's 1963 trip to Cuba, taken with 58 other college students in defiance of U.S. policy. Each subseries is organized alphabetically by topic or title.

The parallels and differences between Viki's and Bobbye's political interests are reflected in their subject files. Both maintained extensive collections of materials on international women's liberation; like her mother, Viki was most interested in the status of women in Latin American nations. Yet while they shared similar social values and political beliefs, Viki's interests often diverged from her mother's. Viki's general files reflect her involvement in International Year of the Woman activities and her interest in population control, as well as her interest in such topics as reproductive rights, family structure, and economic justice.

Viki's great interest in adoption and parenting grew out of her own experiences as a single adoptive parent of a Mexican-born child. The subseries on adoption and parenting includes newsletters and publications of organizations for single parents; research for a book on single adoptive parenting; and miscellaneous clippings, notes, and other materials on issues such as adoptive parenting, international adoption, and gay/lesbian parenting. These materials are arranged alphabetically by topic or title.

The final subseries contains Viki's extensive notes and other materials related to literature. This subseries is organized into coursework, general literature, and Latin American literature, and is arranged alphabetically therein.

The addition (2003-0066) consists primarily of professional and subject files documenting Ortiz's law career, writings, and feminist and social activism. Her work on the literature and women's issues of Latin America are particularly well-represented. Portions of this addition are closed to use until 2050.

Addition (05-024) (3759 items, 7.7 lin. ft.; dated 1923-1997 and n.d) comprises research materials pertaining to gender, women, and the law; artist Elizabeth Catlett; and experimentation with LSD by the U.S. military. Includes family documents about Camilo, Ortiz's adopted son; teaching materials; files from CUNY law school; correspondence, appointment calendars; videotapes; travel diaries; photographs, printed material; and ephemera. This addition is closed to use until 2050.
Acquired as part of the Sallie Bingham Center for Women's History and Culture.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Consists of folders holding articles, reports, speeches, newsclippings, class notes, and various writings by Viki Ortiz and others. Organized into the following subseries: Cuba, Mexico, Latin America, International Women's Liberation, General, Adoption and Parenting, and Literature, which is further subdivided into three subseries. The organization of each subseries is explained under its title.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Note: This series contains pictorial materials and large numbers of newsprint and other fragile materials. Please handle with care. Technical Services staff may need to reformat newsprint, coated fax paper, or other brittle paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: An extensive series of publications, articles, speeches, writings (some by Viki Ortiz), and memorabilia related to the Cuban political and cultural scene primarily of the sixties and seventies. Also includes several maps of Cuba, Photographs, and materials related to Viki's 1963 trip to Cuba as part of a United States student group. Organized alphabetically by topic.

did.unittitle: 1963 Trip -- Student Committee for Travel to Cuba
Articles, Le Monde, 1974 Apr. 6-9, Alain-Marie Carron
Books -- Instituto Cubano del libro, catalogs
Fidel -- conversation with U Thant, UN Secretary General
First and Second Declarations of Havana, 1960, 1962, 1970
Guevara -- The Role of Foreign Aid in the Development of Cuba, 1961
Che Guevara -- Speech to UN, 1964 Dec. 11
Outline, Notes for "Land and People of Cuba"
Poder Popular -- Center for Cuban Studies Newsletter, 1975
Political Documents, 1962-1963 (speeches by Castro and Raul Roa)
Return to Cuba, H. L. Matthews, 1964
Revista de la Universidad de Mexico, 1973

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chiefly articles, clippings, reports, and writings concerning the general politics and culture of Mexico in the twentieth century. The notes were taken by Viki Ortiz on a number of readings relating to Mexico. Contains few periodicals. Organized alphabetically by folder topic.

did.unittitle: Notes on Anita Brenner's The Wind That Swept Mexico>
Notes on Soto y Gama La Revolucion Agraria...
Notes on Lesley Byrd Simpson's Many Mexicos
Notes on John Womack's Zapata: the Mexican Revolution
Things to Follow Up (bibliography, articles, interviews, etc.)
Zapata and Revolution in Popular Song

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Chiefly articles, clippings, reports, and writings concerning the general politics and culture of Central American countries, particularly of El Salvador and Nicaragua, and the South American countries of Chile and Bolivia. Contains few periodicals. Organized alphabetically by folder topic.

did.unittitle: Chile -- report on psychological effects on victims of political abuses in Pinochet regime, 1978

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Folders containing articles, clippings, reports, and publications relating to a broad range of women's issues. The largest grouping of folders is found under the heading for Mexico. Organized alphabetically by country.

did.unittitle: Latin America -- Bibliography, Women in Latin America
Mexico -- Movimiento de Liberación de la Mujer
Puerto Rico -- Family ( The Puerto Rican Family of Today, Mendez, 1954)
Puerto Rico -- Women ( Contemporary Puerto Rican Stories: Spotlight on Woman, VO, 1972)
US -- Texas, Women in the Texas Workforce..," 1979)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Folders containing articles, newsclippings, reports, bibliographies, and notes on a variety of general topics, including many materials on parenting, population control, and reproductive rights. Several writings by Viki Ortiz appear in this subseries. Organized alphabetically by topic. A large group of periodicals is filed under "Publications," and therein by title.

did.unittitle: International Year of the Woman (3 folders), 1975-1976
International Year of the Woman -- Commercialization, 1975
International Year of the Woman -- Mexico, 1975
Marxism -- El marxismo, mariategui, y el movimiento femenino
Population Control -- El desarrollo de la poblacion bajo el capitalismo
Population Control -- Repression in Latin America
Population Control -- Population Control in the Third World: Free Choice or Coercion?, VO
Population Policies and Growth in Latin America, 1971
Publications -- FPS: A Magazine of Youth Liberation, 1976
Publications -- The Second Cultural Revolution - And Why We Need It
Publications -- Women's International League For Peace and Freedom, 1975
VO 1969 Paper on Women -- Women: An Oppressed Majority
Adoption and Parenting Subseries, [ca. 1979]-1983 and undated

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: These files of articles, newsletters, newsclippings, notes, and other materials reflect Viki Ortiz's intense interest in issues surrounding adoption, single parent families, and gay/lesbian parenting. Also documented in these files is her participation in local organizations in New York State and New Jersey, as well as her initial preparations for a book on adoption. Contains some folders of correspondence. Organized alphabetically by topic.

did.unittitle: Adoption Book -- Notes for VO's book
North American Council on Adoptable Children (NACAC)
Pre-School Association of the West Side, Inc. (PAWS)
Raíces, Hispanic Adoption Program, NY COAC., 1983

Single Parent Resource Center, San Francisco (information)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: This container list describes only those materials that are currently open for research. Other materials are closed until 2050.
Note: in many cases the donor has made notes on the folders themselves which give contextual information about the contents.
